document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the genus Ta mb ana Moore, 1882 with description of eight new species and one subspecies (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae: Pantheinae). Revision of Pantheinae, contribution XIII

subSubSection.paragraph:
Trisuloides contaminata
Draudt, 1937
, Entomologische Rundschau , 54 : 399 , Pl. 4 :
2 f.
Type-locality: China , Yunnan, Zhejiang, Shandong. Syntypes : ZFMK .

Synonymy:
Trisuloides tamsi
Park & Lee, 1977
, Korean Journal of Entomology 7 : 1 , fig. 1 . Holotype : S. Korea , Seoul, coll. Agric. Sci. Inst. Suweon.

Material examined. Types .
Syntypes of
Trisuloides contaminata Draudt
( ZFMK ) and holotype of
Xanthomantis tamsi Park & Lee
( NIAES , Suwon, Republica Korea ). Other material examined. CHINA :
1 male
, Prov. Hubei, Tapieh Shan [Daba Shan], 1400 m , Cheng, ex coll.,
21 .vi. 2001
, coll. PG;
1 male
, Prov. Shaanxi, Taibei Shan, Tsinling Mts, [Qinling], Shou-Man, 15 km S 1800 m ,
32 °08′N
,
108 ° 37 ′E
, Sinyaev V. & Plutenko A. leg.,
25 .v.– 14 .vi. 2000
, coll. GB/ ZSM ; 1 m , Prov. Shaanxi, Taibei Shan, Tsinling Mts, [Qinling], Houzhenzi, Umg, 2600–3000 m ,
33 ° 52 ′N
,

, collector unknown,

, slide GB 8530 male;

,

, Prov. Sichuan, Siguilang Shan, Volong Reserve,

, Primorye terr., Ussurijsk Distr., Suputinsky Nature reserve,,

,

, collector unknown
24 .iv. 1960
, slide Kobes Prp. 100 / 77 , det. as
cornelia
, coll. Kobes, coll. ZSM ;
1 male
,
1 female
Russia , Primorye terr., Kedrovaya pad Nature reserve,
7–12 .vi. 1986
, V. Kononenko leg., coll. IBSS .

Diagnosis. (
Fig. 132
). Wingspan 36–38 mm .
X . contaminata
differs from
X. cornelia
by more rounded wing shape, darker and more blackish forewing, without bluish-grey tint and without central white spot, wing pattern formed by waved lines and by presence of whitish suffusion around the reniform stigma toward postmedial line.

Male genitalia (
Fig. 134
). In male genitalia, it differs from
X. cornelia
in somewhat wider valva with wider harpe and denser field of cornuti in vesica.

Female genitalia (
Fig. 136
). Female differs from
X. cornelia
by wider antrum and less sclerotised area in caudal part of bursae.

Distribution and bionomy. Russian Far East (Primorye and South Khabarovsk Terr., Amur reg.), Korea , Northwest, Central and Southwest China (Provs Shaanxi, Hubei, Sichuan, Yunnan). The species occurs in broadleaved forests with oak. Moths fly in end of April, May and early June, syntopically and synchronously with preceding species. Larvae feed on
Quercus mongolica
,
Q . dentata
( Fagaceae ) and probably on other oak species.
